info.title: ānupubbí
info.first:
'gradual instruction', progressive sermon; given by the Buddha when it 
was necessary to prepare first the listener's mind before speaking to him on the 
advanced teaching of the Four Noble Truths. The stock passage (e.g. D. 3; D 14; 
M. 56) runs as follows:

info.titleEn2: object. There are six: visible object
info.title: ārammana
info.first:
'object'. There are six: visible object, sound, odor, taste, 
body-impression, mind-object.

info.title: āsava
info.first: (lit: influxes), 'cankers', taints, corruption's, intoxicant biases.

info.titleEn2: advertence of the mind towards the object
info.title: āvajjana
info.first:
'advertence' of the mind towards the object, forms the first stage in 
the process of consciousness (s. viññāna-kicca).

info.title: āyatana
info.first:
1. 'spheres', is a name for the four immaterial absorptions; s. 
jhāna (5-8).

info.title: āyúhana
info.first:
(karmic) 'accumulation', is a name used in the commentarial literature 
for the wholesome and unwholesome volitional activities (karma, q.v.) or 
karma-formations (sankhāra; s. paticca-samuppāda), being the bases 
of future rebirth.

info.title: abhabbāgamana
info.first: 'incapable of progressing'.

info.title: abhibhāyatana
info.first:
the 8 'stages of mastery', are powers to be obtained by means of the 
kasina-exercises (s. kasina). In the Com. 
to M.77, where āyatana is explained by 'means' (kārana) it is 
said: "The abhibhāyatana through their counteracting may master 
(suppress) the adverse states, and by means of higher knowledge they may master 
the objects of mind." They are means for transcending the sensuous sphere.

info.title: abhiññā
info.first:
The 6 'higher powers', or supernormal knowledge's, consist of 5 mundane (lokiya) 
powers attainable through the utmost perfection in mental concentration (samādhi) and one supermundane (lokuttara) 
power attainable through penetrating insight (vipassanā), 
i.e. extinction of all cankers (āsavakkhaya; s. 
āsava), in other words, realization of Arahatship or Holiness.

info.title: abhisamācārika
info.first: 'morality consisting in good behaviour',

info.title: abhisamaya
info.first: 'truth-realization',

info.titleEn2: lit. That which cannot or should not be thought
info.title: acinteyya
info.first:
lit. 'That which cannot or should not be thought, the unthinkable, 
incomprehensible, impenetrable, that which transcends the limits of thinking and 
over which therefore one should not ponder.

info.title: adhimokkha
info.first: 'determination', decision, resolve:

info.title: adhitthāna
info.first: as a doctrinal term, occurs chiefly in two meanings:

info.title: ādibrahmacariyaka
info.first: 'morality of genuine pure conduct',

info.titleEn2: knowledge consisting in contemplation of misery
info.title: ādínavānupassanā
info.first: 'knowledge consisting in contemplation of misery',

info.title: agati
info.first: the 4 'wrong paths' are:

info.title: āhāra
info.first: 'nutriment', 'food',

info.titleEn2: lack of moral shame and dread
info.title: ahirika
info.first: 'lack of moral shame and dread',

info.title: ākāsa
info.first: 'space', is, according to Com., of two kinds:

info.title: akuppa
info.first:
'unshakable', is one who has attained full mastery over the absorptions 
(jhāna).

info.titleEn2:
general unwholesome mental factors associated with all unwholesome 
actions (volitions)
info.title: akusala
info.first:
'general unwholesome mental factors associated with all unwholesome 
actions' (volitions), are four:

info.title: akusala
info.first: 'unwholesome thoughts'

info.title: akusala
info.first: 'unwholesome',

info.title: āloka
info.first: 'perception of light'.

info.titleEn2:
(Sanskrit amrta; √
mr to die; = Gr. ambrosia): Deathlessness
info.title: amata
info.first:
(Sanskrit amrta; √
mr to die; = Gr. ambrosia): 'Deathlessness'

info.title: Anāgāmí
info.first:
the 'Non-Returner', is a noble disciple (ariya-puggala) 
on the 3rd stage of holiness.

info.titleEn2: the 5 heinous actions with immediate destiny are:
info.title: ānantarika
info.first: the 5 heinous 'actions with immediate destiny' are:

info.title: ānantariya
info.first:
the 'Immediacy', is a name for that concentration of mind which is 
associated with such insight (vipassanā) 
as is present in any one of the 4 kinds of supermundane path consciousness (s. 
ariya-puggala), and which therefore is the cause of the immediately 
following consciousness as its result or 'fruition' (phala).

info.title: ānāpāna
info.first: 'mindfulness on in-and-out-breathing',

info.title: anattā
info.first: 'not-self', non-ego, egolessness, impersonality,

info.title: anicca
info.first: 'impermanent' (or, as abstract noun, aniccatā, 'impermanence')

info.title: anicca
info.first:
'perception of impermanence', is defined in the Girimananda Sutta (A.X. 
60) as meditation on the impermanence of the five groups of existence.

info.title: aññā
info.first:
'highest knowledge', gnosis, refers to the perfect knowledge of the Saint 
(Arahat; s. ariya-puggala).

info.title: anuloma
info.first: 'adaptation-moment of consciousness',

info.title: anuloma
info.first: 'adaptation-knowledge' or conformity-knowledge,

info.titleEn2:
contemplation - 4 fold: s. 
satipatthāna 
- 18 fold: s. vipassanā. 
- 7 fold:
info.title: anupassanā
info.first:
'contemplation' - 4 fold: s. 
satipatthāna 
- 18 fold: s. vipassanā. 
- 7 fold:

info.title: anupubba
info.first:
The 9 'successive extinctions', are the 8 extinctions reached through 
the 8 absorptions (jhāna, q.v.) and the extinction of feeling and 
perception' (s. nirodha-samāpatti), as it is said in A. IX, 31 and D. 33:

info.title: anupubba
info.first:
the 9 'successive abodes', are identical with the 9 anupubba-nirodha 
(s. above).

info.title: anusaya
info.first:
the 7 'proclivities', inclinations, or tendencies are: sensuous greed (kāma-rāga, 
s. 
samyojana), grudge (patigha), 
speculative opinion (ditthi), sceptical 
doubt (vicikicchā), 
conceit (māna), craving for continued 
existence (bhavarāga), ignorance (avijjā) 
(D.33; A.VII.11-12).

info.title: anussati
info.first:
'recollection', meditation, contemplation. The six recollections often 
described in the Suttas (e.g. A.VI.10, 25; D.33) are:

info.title: apāya
info.first: The 4 'lower worlds'. are:

info.title: aparihāna
info.first:
'incapable of relapse', or 'of falling away', namely, with regard to 
deliverance from some or all fetters of existence (s. samyojana).

info.title: aparihāniya
info.first: 'conditions of welfare' (lit. of non-decline), for a nation.

info.title: appamāda
info.first:
'zeal', non-laxity, earnestness, diligence, is considered as the 
  foundation of all progress.

info.titleEn2: attainment concentration or full concentration (from apeti
info.title: appanā
info.first:
'attainment concentration' or 'full concentration' (from apeti, 
to fix), is the concentration existing during absorption (jhāna, q.v.), 
whilst the neighbourhood or access-concentration (upacāra-samādhi) 
only approaches the 1st absorption without attaining it; s. samādhi.

info.title: ariya
info.first: 'Noble Ones', 'noble persons'.

info.title: ariya
info.first:
The four 'noble usage's', are: contentedness (of the monk) with any 
robe, contentedness with any alms-food, contentedness with any dwelling, and 
delight in meditation and detachment. In the Ariya-vamsa Sutta, (A. IV , 28) and 
similarly in D. 33, it is said :

info.titleEn2:
an Abhidhamma term signifying a state of consciousness arisen 
spontaneously
info.title: asankhārika
info.first:
an Abhidhamma term signifying a 'state of consciousness arisen 
spontaneously', i.e. without previous deliberation, preparation, or prompting by 
others; hence: 'unprepared, unprompted'.

info.title: asañña
info.first:
The 'unconscious beings', are a class of heavenly beings in the 
fine-material world; s. deva (II).

info.title: asekha
info.first:
(lit.: 'not-learner'; s. sekha), a disciple 'perfected in 
training', one beyond training, an adept.

info.title: asmi
info.first:
(lit.: 'I am'-conceit), 'ego-conceit', may range from the coarsest pride 
and self-assertion to a subtle feeling of one's distinctiveness or superiority 
that persists, as the 8th fetter (samyojana), until the attainment 
of Arahatship or Holiness.

info.title: assāsa
info.first:
'in-and-out-breathing', are corporeal or physical functions or 
'formations' (kāya-sankhāra), whilst thought-conception and discursive 
thinking (vitakka and vicāra) are called verbal functions (vacī-sankhāra), 
s. 
sankhāra (2).

info.title: asubha
info.first: 'impurity', loathsomeness, foulness. -

info.title: atappa
info.first:
'the unworried', is the name of a class of deities (s. deva) 
inhabiting the first of the five Pure Abodes (suddhāvāsa), in which 
the Anāgāmī (q.v.) has his last rebirth.

info.title: attā
info.first: 'self, ego, personality,

info.title: atta
info.first:
'self-mortification', is one of the two extremes to be avoided, the 
other extreme being addiction to sensual pleasures (kāma-sukha), whilst 
the Noble 8-fold Path constitutes the Middle Path (majjhima-patipadā, 
q.v.).

info.title: avacara
info.first: 'sphere', realm. The 3 spheres of existence are:

info.title: aviha
info.first: (derivation uncertain; Sanskrit avrha)

info.title: avihimsā
info.first:
(equivalents: ahimsā, avihesā): 'harmlessness', nonviolence, 
absence of cruelty.

info.title: avijjā
info.first:
'ignorance,' nescience, unknowing; synonymous with delusion (moha, 
s. mūla), is the primary root of all evil 
and suffering in the world, veiling man's mental eyes and preventing him from 
seeing the true nature of things. It is the delusion tricking beings by making 
life appear to them as permanent, happy, substantial and beautiful and 
preventing them from seeing that everything in reality is impermanent, liable to 
suffering, void of 'I' and 'mine', and basically impure (s. 
vipallāsa). Ignorance is defined as 'not 
knowing the four truths, namely, suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the 
way to its cessation' (S. XII, 4).

info.title: avikkhepa
info.first: 'undistractedness', is a synonym of

info.titleEn2:
lit. indeterminate - i.e. neither determined as karmically wholesome 
nor as unwholesome - are the karmically neutral
info.title: avyākata
info.first:
lit. 'indeterminate' - i.e. neither determined as karmically 'wholesome' 
nor as 'unwholesome' - are the karmically neutral, i.e. amoral, states of 
consciousness and mental factors.

info.title: avyāpāda
info.first:
'hatelessness', non-ill-will, goodness; is one of the three kinds of 
right thought (s. sacca, IV. 2), or wholesome thoughts (vitakka) and is the 9th of the 10 wholesome courses of actions (kammapatha 
II. q.v.).

info.title: bala
info.first: 'powers'

info.title: bhāva
info.first: (feminine and masculine) 'nature',

info.title: bhāvanā
info.first:
'mental development' (lit. 'calling into existence, producing') is what 
in English is generally but rather vaguely called 'meditation'. One has to 
distinguish 2 kinds:

info.title: bhava
info.first: 'becoming', 'process of existence', consists of 3 planes:

info.titleEn2:
The first term may tentatively be rendered as the undercurrent forming the 
condition of being
info.title: bhavanga
info.first:
The first term may tentatively be rendered as the 'undercurrent forming the 
condition of being, or existence', and the second as 'subconsciousness', though, 
as will be evident from the following, it differs in several respects from the 
usage of that term in Western psychology.

info.titleEn2: knowledge consisting in the awareness of terror
info.title: bhayatupatthāna
info.first: 'knowledge consisting in the awareness of terror',

info.titleEn2: A fully ordained disciple of the Buddha is called a bhikkhu.
info.title: bhikkhu
info.first: A fully ordained disciple of the Buddha is called a bhikkhu.

info.title: bhojane mattaññutā
info.first: 'knowing the measure in eating'.

info.title: bodhi
info.first:
(from verbal root budhi, to awaken, to understand): awakenment, 
enlightenment, supreme knowledge. "(Through Bodhi) one awakens from the slumber 
or stupor (inflicted upon the mind) by the defilements (kilesa) 
and comprehends the Four Noble Truths (sacca)" 
(Com. to M. 10).

info.title: bodhipakkhiya
info.first:
The 37 'things pertaining to enlightenment', or 'requisites of 
enlightenment' comprise the entire doctrines of the Buddha.

info.title: Bodhisatta
info.first:
'Enlightenment Being', is a being destined to Buddha-hood, a future 
Buddha.

info.title: bojjhanga
info.first: 'the 7 factors of enlightenment', are:

info.title: brahma
info.first: 'pure (chaste) or holy life', is a term for the life of the monk.

info.titleEn2:
The heavenly beings of the Brahma-world inhabit the first 3 heavens of 
the fine-material world
info.title: brahma
info.first:
The 'heavenly beings of the Brahma-world' inhabit the first 3 heavens of 
the fine-material world, (rūpaloka),
corresponding to the 1st absorption (jhāna, q.v.).

info.title: brahma
info.first:
'Brahma-world', in the widest sense, is a name for the fine-material 
(rūpa-loka) and immaterial world (arūpa-loka);

info.title: brahma
info.first:
the 4 'sublime' or 'divine abodes', also called the 4 boundless states 
(appamaññā), are:

info.title: cāga
info.first:
'liberality', is one of the 'blessings' (s. 
sampadā),

info.titleEn2: morality consisting in performance and morality consisting in avoidance
info.title: cāritta
info.first: 'morality consisting in performance and morality consisting in avoidance,'

info.title: cakka
info.first:
'wheel', is one of the seven 'precious possessions' (ratana) of a 
righteous World Emperor (cakkavatti: 
'He who owns the Wheel,' cf. D. 26), and symbolizes conquering progress and 
expanding sovereignty. From that derives the figurative expression 
dhamma-cakkam pavatteti, 'he sets rolling the Wheel of the Law' and the name 
of the Buddha's first sermon, Dhamma-cakkappavattana Sutta (s. dhamma-cakka).

info.title: cakkhu
info.first: 'eye' s. āyatana. -

info.title: carita
info.first: 'nature, character'.

info.title: catu
info.first:
'four-group existence', is the existence in the immaterial world 
(arūpa-loka; s. loka), since only the four mental groups (feeling, 
perception, mental formations, consciousness, s. khandha) are found 
there, the corporeality group being absent. Cf. pañca-vokāra-bhava, 
eka-vokāra-bhava. (App.: vokāra).

info.title: cetanā
info.first:
'volition', will, is one of the seven mental factors (cetasika, 
q.v.) inseparably bound up with all consciousness, namely sensorial or mental 
impression (phassa), feeling (vedanā), 
perception (saññā), volition (cetanā), concentration (samādhi),
vitality (jīvita), advertence (manasikāra). Cf. Tab. II, Tab. III.

info.title: cetasika
info.first:
'mental things, mental factors', are those mental concomitants which are 
bound up with the simultaneously arising consciousness (citta = viññāna) 
and conditioned by its presence.

info.title: cetaso vinibandha
info.first:
'mental bondages', are 5 things which hinder the mind from making right 
exertion, namely:

info.titleEn2:
deliverance of mind. In the highest sense it signifies the fruition of 
Arahatship (s. ariya-puggala)
info.title: ceto
info.first:
'deliverance of mind'. In the highest sense it signifies the fruition of 
Arahatship (s. ariya-puggala), and in particular, the concentration 
associated with it. It is often linked with the 'deliverance through wisdom' 
(paññā-vimutti, q.v.), e.g. in the ten powers of a Perfect One (s. 
dasa-bala). See vimokkha I.

info.title: cetokhila
info.first:
'mental obduracies', are 5 things which stiffen and hinder the mind from 
making right exertion, namely:

info.title: chanda
info.first: intention, desire, will.

info.title: citta
info.first:
'mind', 'consciousness', 'state of consciousness', is a synonym of 
mano and 
viññāna (s. khandha and
Tab. 1).

info.title: citta
consciousness
info.first: viññāna (s. khandha),

info.title: dāna
info.first: 'almsgiving', liberality, offering.

info.titleEn2: the ten powers (of a Perfect One); or
info.title: dasa
info.first:
'the ten powers (of a Perfect One); or, he who Possesses the 10 P.', 
i.e. the Buddha.

info.title: deliverance
info.first: s. vimutti, vimokkha. -

info.title: desanā
info.first:
'exposition' of the doctrine, may be either an exposition true in the 
highest sense (paramattha-desanā); or it may not be true in the highest, 
but only in the conventional sense (vohāra-desanā).

info.titleEn2:
(lit: the Radiant Ones; related to Lat. deus):
heavenly beings
info.title: deva
info.first:
(lit: the Radiant Ones; related to Lat. deus):
heavenly beings, deities, celestials, are beings who live in happy worlds, 
and who, as a rule, are invisible to the human eye.

info.title: deva
info.first:
'divine messengers', is a symbolic name for old age, disease and death, 
since these three things remind man of his future and rouse him to earnest 
striving. In A. III, 35, it is said:

info.title: dhātu
info.first: 'elements', are the ultimate constituents of a whole.

info.title: dhātu
info.first:
'analysis (or determining) of the 4 elements', is described in Vis.M. 
XI, 2, as the last of the 40 mental exercises (s. 
bhāvanā).

info.title: dhamma
info.first:
lit. the 'bearer', constitution (or nature of a thing), norm, law 
(jus), doctrine; justice, righteousness; quality; thing, object of mind (s. 
āyatana) 'phenomenon'. In all these meanings the word 'dhamma' is 
to be met with in the texts.

info.title: dhamma
info.first:
The 'Wheel (realm) of the Law', is a name for the doctrine 'set rolling' 
(established) by the Buddha, i.e. the 4 Noble Truths (sacca, q.v.).

info.titleEn2: Knowledge of the Fixity of Law
info.title: Dhamma
info.first: 'Knowledge of the Fixity of Law',

info.title: dhana
info.first: 'treasures', a term for the following 7 qualities:

info.titleEn2:
(lit. means of shaking off (the defilements)); means of 
purification
info.title: dhutānga
info.first:
(lit. 'means of shaking off (the defilements)'); 'means of 
purification', ascetic or austere practices. These are strict observances 
recommended by the Buddha to monks as a help to cultivate contentedness, 
renunciation, energy and the like. One or more of them may be observed for a 
shorter or longer period of time.

info.title: dibba-cakkhu
info.first: the 'divine eye',

info.title: ditthi
info.first:
(lit. 'sight'; Ö dis, 
to see): view, belief, speculative opinion, insight.

info.title: domanassa
info.first: lit. 'sad-mindedness', grief,

info.title: dukkha
info.first:
(1) 'pain', painful feeling, which may be bodily and mental (s. 
vedanā).

info.titleEn2: (abstr. noun fr. dukkha): the state of suffering
info.title: dukkhatā
info.first:
(abstr. noun fr. dukkha): 'the state of suffering', painfulness, 
unpleasantness, the unsatisfactoriness of existence. "There are three kinds of 
suffering:

info.title: gantha
info.first: 'ties'. "There are 4 ties:

info.title: gati
info.first: (lit. 'going'): 'course of existence', destiny, destination.

info.titleEn2: lit. who has entered the lineage (of the Noble Ones)
info.title: gotrabhú
info.first:
lit. 'who has entered the lineage (of the Noble Ones)', i.e. the Matured 
One.

info.titleEn:
h.-b.-samādhi, h.-b.-paññā:
morality, concentration or wisdom...
info.title: hāna
info.first:
h.-b.-samādhi, h.-b.-paññā:
morality, concentration or wisdom connected with decline.

info.titleEn2: heart as physical base of mental life.
info.title: hadaya
info.first: 'heart as physical base' of mental life.

info.title: hasituppāda
info.first:
lit. 'consciousness producing mirth' (smile), is found in the 
Abhidhammattha Sangaha as a name for the joyful mind-consciousness element 
(manoviññāna-dhātu, Tab. I. 72) arising as functional consciousness 
independent of karma (kiriya-citta), only in the Arahat. - (App.).

info.title: hetu
info.first:
'cause', condition, reason; (Abhidhamma) root-condition. In sutta usage 
it is almost synonymous with paccaya,
'condition', and often occurs together with it ('What is the cause, what is the 
condition', ko hetu ko paccayo).

info.title: hiri
info.first:
'moral shame and moral dread', are associated with all karmically 
wholesome consciousness (s. Tab. II).

info.title: iddhi
info.first:
'power', 'magical power'. The magical powers constitute one of the 6 
kinds of higher spiritual powers (abhiññā, q.v.). One distinguishes many 
kinds of magical powers:

info.titleEn2: roads to power (or success) are the 4 following qualities
info.title: iddhi
info.first:
'roads to power' (or success) are the 4 following qualities, "for as 
guides, they indicate the road to power connected therewith; and because they 
form, by way of preparation, the roads to the power constituting the fruition of 
the path" (Vis.M. XII), namely:

info.title: indriya
info.first:
'faculties', is a name for 22, partly physical, partly mental, phenomena 
often treated in the Suttas as well as in the Abhidhamma. They are:

info.title: indriya
info.first:
'equilibrium, balance, or harmony of faculties', relates to the 5 
spiritual faculties:

info.titleEn:
full understanding through: tīranapariññā,
s. pariññā....
info.title: investigation
info.first:
full understanding through: tīranapariññā,
s. pariññā. -

info.title: iriyā
info.first:
(lit. 'ways of movement'): 'bodily postures', i.e. going, standing, 
sitting, lying. In the Satipatthāna-sutta (s. satipatthāna),
they form the subject of a contemplation and an exercise in mindfulness.

info.title: jāti
info.first:
'birth', comprises the entire embryonic process beginning with 
conception and ending with parturition.

info.title: javana
info.first:
(fr. javati, to impel): 'impulsion', is the phase of full 
cognition in the cognitive series, or perceptual process (citta-vīthi;
s. viññāna-kicca) occurring at its climax, if the respective object 
is large or distinct. It is at this phase that karma is produced, i.e. wholesome 
or unwholesome volition concerning the perception that was the object of the 
previous stages of the respective process of consciousness.

info.titleEn2:
absorption (meditation) refers chiefly to the four meditative 
absorptions of the fine-material sphere (rūpa-jjhāna or
rūpāvacara-jjhāna; s. avacara).
info.title: jhāna
info.first:
'absorption' (meditation) refers chiefly to the four meditative 
absorptions of the fine-material sphere (rūpa-jjhāna or
rūpāvacara-jjhāna; s. avacara).

info.title: jíva
info.first:
life, vital principle, individual soul. 'Soul (life) and body are 
identical' and 'Soul and body are different', these two frequently quoted wrong 
views fall under the 2 kinds of personality-belief (sakkāya-ditthi;
s. ditthi), i.e. the first one under the annihilation-belief 
(uccheda-ditthi)
and the second under the eternity-belief (sassata-ditthi).

info.title: kāma may denote
info.first: may denote:

info.titleEn2:
lit. wrong or evil conduct with regard to sensual things; unlawful 
sexual intercourse refers to adultery
info.title: kāmesu
info.first:
lit. 'wrong or evil conduct with regard to sensual things'; 'unlawful 
sexual intercourse' refers to adultery, and to intercourse with minors or other 
persons under guardianship.

info.title: kāya
info.first:
(lit: accumulation): 'group', 'body', may either refer to the physical 
body (rūpa-kāya) or to the mental body (nāma-kāya).

info.titleEn2: mindfulness with regard to the body
info.title: kāya
info.first:
'mindfulness with regard to the body', refers sometimes (e.g. Vis.M. 
VIII.2) only to the contemplation on the 32 parts of the body, sometimes (e.g. 
M.119) to all the various meditations comprised under the 'contemplation of the 
body' (kāyānupassanā), the 1st of the 4 'foundations of mindfulness' 
(satipatthāna, q.v.), consisting partly in concentration (samādhi) 
exercises, partly in insight (vipassanā) exercises. On the other hand, 
the cemetery meditations (sīvathika, q.v.) mentioned in the Satipatthāna 
S. (M.10) are nearly the same as the 10 contemplations of loathsomeness 
(asubha-bhāvanā, q.v.). of Vis.M. VI, whereas elsewhere the contemplation on 
the 32 parts of the body is called the 'reflection on impurity' 
(patikkūla-saññā).

info.title: kāya
info.first:
'body-witness', is one of the 7 noble disciples (s. 
ariya-puggala, B.).

info.title: kalāpa
info.first: 'group', 'unit':

info.title: kalyāna
info.first:
'noble (or good) friend', is called a senior monk who is the mentor and 
friend of his pupil, "wishing for his welfare and concerned with his progress", 
guiding his meditation; in particular, the meditation teacher 
(kammatthānācariya) is so called.

info.title: kamma
info.first:
'course of action', is a name for the group of 10 kinds of either 
unwholesome or wholesome actions, viz.

info.title: kammaññatā
info.first: 'adaptability', i.e. of

info.title: kankhā
info.first:
'doubt', may be either an intellectual, critical doubt or an ethically 
and psychologically detrimental doubt. The latter may either be a persistent 
negative skepticism or wavering indecision. Only the detrimental doubt 
(identical with vicikicchā, q.v.) is to be rejected as karmically 
unwholesome, as it paralyses thinking and hinders the inner development of man. 
Reasoned, critical doubt in dubious matters is thereby not discouraged.

info.title: kappa
info.first:
(Sanskrit kalpa): 'world-period', an inconceivably long space of 
time, an aeon. This again is subdivided into 4 sections:

info.title: karma
info.first:
'action', correctly speaking denotes the wholesome and unwholesome volitions 
(kusala- and
akusala-cetanā) and their concomitant mental factors, causing rebirth and 
shaping the destiny of beings.

info.title: karma
info.first:
sankhāra, i.e. wholesome or unwholesome volitions (cetanā) 
manifested as actions of body, speech or mind, form the 2nd link of the formula 
of dependent origination (paticca-samuppāda,
q.v.).

info.title: kasina
info.first:
(perhaps related to Sanskrit krtsna, 'all, complete, whole'), is the 
name for a purely external device to produce and develop concentration of mind 
and attain the 4 absorptions (jhāna q.v.).

info.titleEn2:
the 5 groups (of existence) or groups of clinging 
(upādānakkhandha); alternative renderings: aggregates
info.title: khandha
info.first:
the 5 'groups (of existence)' or 'groups of clinging' 
(upādānakkhandha); alternative renderings: aggregates, categories of 
clinging's objects.

info.titleEn2: the celestial beings corruptible by pleasures
info.title: khidda
info.first: 'the celestial beings corruptible by pleasures', are a class of devas (q.v.) of the sensuous sphere.

info.title: kilesa
info.first:
'defilements', are mind-defiling, unwholesome qualities. Vis.M. XXII, 
49, 65:

info.title: kiñcana
info.first: 'something', i.e. something evil that sticks or adheres to character.

info.titleEn2: functional consciousness or karmically inoperative consciousness
info.title: kiriya
info.first:
'functional consciousness' or 'karmically inoperative consciousness', is a 
name for such states of consciousness as are neither karmically wholesome 
(kusala), nor unwholesome (akusala), nor karma-results (vipāka); 
that is, they function independently of karma.

info.title: kukkucca
info.first: lit. 'wrongly-performed-ness' (ku+krta+ya),

info.title: kuppa
info.first:
'liable to perturbation', is one who has not yet attained full mastery 
over the absorptions.

info.title: kusala
info.first:
'karmically wholesome' or 'profitable', salutary, morally good, 
(skillful)

info.titleEn2: the wholesome roots or roots of wholesome action
info.title: kusala
info.first: the 'wholesome roots' or 'roots of wholesome action', are

info.title: loka
info.first:
'world', denotes the 3 spheres of existence comprising the whole 
universe, i.e.

info.title: lokiya
info.first: 'mundane',

info.title: lokuttara
info.first: 'supermundane',

info.title: māna
info.first:
'conceit', pride, is one of the 10 fetters binding to existence (s. 
samyojana). It vanishes completely only at the entrance to Arahatship, 
or Holiness (cf. asmi-māna). It is further one of the proclivities (s. 
anusaya) and defilements (s. 
kilesa). "

info.title: Māra
info.first:
(lit. 'the killer'), is the Buddhist 'Tempter-figure. He is often called 
'Māra the Evil One' (pāpimā māro)
or Namuci (lit. 'the non-liberator', i.e. the opponent of liberation). He 
appears in the texts both as a real person (i.e. as a deity) and as 
personification of evil and passions, of the totality of worldly existence, and 
of death. Later Pāli literature often speaks of a 'fivefold Māra' 
(pañca-māra):
1. M. as a deity (devaputta-māra), 2. the M. of defilements 
(kilesa-m.),
3. the M. of the aggregates (khandha-m.), 4. the M. of the 
karma-formations (kamma-m.), and 5. Māra as death (maccu-m.).

info.title: mada
info.first: 'infatuation'. "Infatuation is of 3 kinds:

info.title: magga
info.first: 'path'.

info.title: mahaggata
info.first:
lit., 'grown great', i.e. 'developed', exalted, supernormal. As 
mahaggata-citta, it is the state of 'developed consciousness', attained in 
the fine-material and immaterial absorptions (s.
jhāna); it is mentioned in the mind-contemplation of the Satipatthāna Sutta 
(M. 10). -

info.title: majjhimā
info.first:
'Middle Path', is the Noble Eightfold Path which, by avoiding the two 
extremes of sensual lust and self-torment, leads to enlightenment and 
deliverance from suffering.

info.title: manasikāra
info.first: 'attention', 'mental advertence', 'reflection'.

info.title: mangala
info.first:
means, in general usage, anything regarded as 'auspicious' 'lucky', or a 
'good omen'.

info.title: mano
info.first:
'mind', is in the Abhidhamma used as synonym of viññāna
(consciousness) and citta (state of consciousness, mind).

info.title: mano
info.first: 'mind-element', is one of the 18 elements (s. dhātu II).

info.titleEn2: the celestial beings corruptible by temper
info.title: manopadosika
info.first:
'the celestial beings corruptible by temper', are a class of devas 
(q.v.) of the sensuous sphere.

info.titleEn2:
mental indulging. There are mentioned 18 ways of indulging: 6 in 
gladness (somanassūpavicāra)
info.title: manopavicāra
info.first:
'mental indulging'. There are mentioned 18 ways of indulging: 6 in 
gladness (somanassūpavicāra), 6 in sorrow (domanassa),
6 in indifference (upekkhā).

info.title: manovinñāna
info.first:
'mind-consciousness element', one of the 18 'elements' (s. dhātu 
II).

info.title: marana
info.first:
'death', in ordinary usage, means the disappearance of the vital faculty 
confined to a single life-time, and therewith of the psycho-physical 
life-process conventionally called 'man, animal, personality, ego', etc. 
Strictly speaking, however, death is the continually repeated dissolution and 
vanishing of each momentary physical-mental combination, and thus it takes place 
every moment. About this momentaneity of existence, it is said in Vis.M. VIII:

info.title: maranānussati
info.first:
'recollection of death', is one of the 10 recollections treated in 
detail in Vis.M. VIII:

info.title: meat
info.first:
Just as the karmical, i.e. moral, quality of any action is determined by 
the quality of volition (cetanā) underlying it, and independently of this 
volition nothing whatever can be called karmically wholesome or unwholesome 
(kusala, akusala), just so it is with the merely external act of 
meat-eating, this being as such purely non-moral, i.e. karmically neutral 
(avyākata).

info.title: micchā
info.first: Atthangika: the 'eightfold wrong path', i.e.

info.title: múla
info.first:
'roots', also called hetu (q.v.; s.
 paccaya,
1), are those conditions which through their presence determine the actual 
moral quality of a volitional state (cetanā), and the consciousness and 
mental factors associated therewith, in other words, the quality of 
karma.

info.title: nāma
info.first: (lit. 'name'): 'mind', mentality.

info.title: nāma
info.first:
the 'mind-group' (as distinguished from rūpa-kāya,
the corporeality-group) comprises the 4 immaterial groups of existence 
(arūpino khandhā; s. khandha).

info.title: nāma
info.first:
(lit. 'name and form'): 'mind-and-body', mentality and corporeality. It 
is the 4th link in the dependent origination (s. paticcasamuppāda
3, 4) where it is conditioned by consciousness, and on its part is the condition 
of the sixfold sense-base. In two texts (D. 14, 15), which contain variations of 
the dependent origination, the mutual conditioning of consciousness and 
mind-and-body is described (see also S. XII, 67), and the latter is said to be a 
condition of sense-impression (phassa); so also in Sn. 872.

info.title: ñānadassana
info.first:
'purification of knowledge and vision', is the last of the 7 
purifications and a name for path-knowledge (maggañāna),
i.e. the penetrating realization of the path of Stream-winning, 
Once-returning, Non-returning or Arahatship. Vis.M. XXII furnishes a detailed 
explanation of it (s. visuddhi, VII).

info.title: nekkhamma
info.first: 'freedom from sensual lust', renunciation.

info.title: neyya
info.first:
'requiring guidance', is said of a person "who through advice and 
questioning, through wise consideration, and through frequenting noble-minded 
friends, having intercourse with them, associating with them, gradually comes to 
penetrate the truth" (Pug. 162). Cf. 
ugghatitaññū.

info.titleEn2: A teaching the meaning of which is implicit
info.title: neyyattha
info.first:
A 'teaching the meaning of which is implicit, or has to be inferred' as 
contrasted with a 'teaching with an explicit or evident meaning' 
(nītattha-dhamma).

info.title: Nibbāna
info.first:
(Sanskrit nirvāna): lit. 'extinction' (nir
+ √ va, to cease blowing, to become 
extinguished); according to the commentaries, 'freedom from desire' (nir+ 
vana). Nibbāna constitutes the highest and ultimate goal of all Buddhist 
aspirations, i.e. absolute extinction of that life-affirming will manifested as 
greed, hate and delusion, and convulsively clinging to existence; and therewith 
also the ultimate and absolute deliverance from all future rebirth, old age, 
disease and death, from all suffering and misery. Cf. Parinibbāna.

info.title: nívarana
info.first:
'hindrances', are 5 qualities which are obstacles to the mind and blind 
our mental vision. In the presence of them we cannot reach 
neighbourhood-concentration (upacāra-samādhi) and full concentration 
(appanā-samādhi), and are unable to discern clearly the truth. They are:

info.title: nimitta
info.first:
mark, sign; image; target, object; cause, condition. These meanings are 
used in, and adapted to, many contexts of which only the doctrinal ones are 
mentioned here.

info.title: nipphanna
info.first:
'produced corporeality', is identical with rūpa-rūpa, 
'corporeality proper', i.e. material or actual corporeality, as contrasted with 
'unproduced corporeality' (anipphanna-rūpa),
consisting of mere qualities or modes of corporeality, e.g. impermanence, etc., 
which are also enumerated among the 28 phenomena of the corporeality group.

info.title: niraya
info.first:
lit. 'the downward-path', the nether or infernal world, usually 
translated by 'hell', is one of the 4 lower courses of existence (apāya).

info.title: nirodha
info.first:
'attainment of extinction' (S. XIV, 11), also called 
saññā-vedayita-nirodha, 'extinction of feeling and perception', is the 
temporary suspension of all consciousness and mental activity, following 
immediately upon the semi-conscious state called 'sphere of 
neither-perception-nor-non-perception' (s. jhāna, 8). The absolutely 
necessary pre-conditions to its attainment are said to be perfect mastery of all 
the 8 absorptions (jhāna), as well as the previous attainment of Anāgāmī 
or Arahantship (s. ariya-puggala).

info.titleEn2: foundation. The 2 wrong foundations of morality are
info.title: nissaya
info.first: 'foundation'. The 2 wrong foundations of morality are

info.titleEn2:
the fixedness of law regarding all things; cf.
tathatā. -
info.title: niyāma
info.first:
the 'fixedness of law' regarding all things; cf.
tathatā. -

info.title: niyata
info.first: 'wrong views with fixed destiny',

info.titleEn2: a person with a fixed destiny
info.title: niyata
info.first: a 'person with a fixed destiny', may be either

info.title: ojā
info.first:
'nutriment' (synonym of āhāra, q.v.), is one of those 8 minimal 
constituent parts, or qualities, of all corporeality, to wit: the solid, liquid, 
heat, motion; colour, odour, taste and nutriment.

info.title: okkanti
info.first:
'conception', lit. 'descent', designates the appearance of the embryo in 
the mother's womb, i.e. the beginning of the birth process (jāti, q.v.).

info.title: opapātika
info.first:
lit. 'accidental' (from upapāta,
accident; not from upapatti, as PTS Dict. has); 'spontaneously born', 
i.e. born without the instrumentality of parents.

info.title: pādaka
info.first:
'foundation-forming absorption', is an absorption used as a foundation, 
or starting point, for the higher spiritual powers (abhiññā), 
or for insight (vipassanā), leading 
to the supermundane paths (s. ariya-puggala).

info.titleEn2: the 4 elements of the effort for purity
info.title: pārisuddhi
info.first: the 4 'elements of the effort for purity', are:

info.title: pārisuddhi
info.first: 'morality consisting in purity',

info.title: pātihāriya
info.first: 'miracle', marvel.

info.title: pātimokkha
info.first:
'Disciplinary Code', is the name of the code of monk's rules, which on 
all full-moon and new moon days is recited before the assembled community of 
fully ordained monks (bhikkhu).

info.title: pabbajjā
info.first:
lit. 'the going forth', or more fully stated, 'the going forth from home 
to the homeless life' of a monk (agārasmā anagāriyam pabbajjā), consists 
in severing all family and social ties to live the pure life of a monk, in order 
to realize the goal of final deliverance pointed out by the Enlightened One. 
Thus, p. has become the name for admission as a sāmanera, or 
novice, i.e. as a candidate for the Order of Bhikkhus, or monks.

info.title: paccavekkhana
info.first:
'retrospective knowledge', refers to the recollected mental image 
obtained in concentration, or to any inner experience just passed, as for 
instance, any absorption (jhāna q.v.), or any supermundane path, or 
fruition of the path, etc. (s. ariya-puggala).

info.title: paccaya
info.first:
'condition', is something on which something else, the so-called 
'conditioned thing', is dependent, and without which the latter cannot be. 
Manifold are the ways in which one thing, or one occurrence, may be the 
condition for some other thing, or occurrence. In the Patthāna, the last book of 
the Abhidhamma Pitaka (comprising 6 large vols. in the Siamese edition), these 
24 modes of conditionality are enumerated and explained, and then applied to all 
conceivable mental and physical phenomena and occurrences, and thus their 
conditioned nature is demonstrated.

info.titleEn2:
an Independently Enlightened One; or Separately or Individually (=pacceka) 
Enlightened One (renderings by Silent or Private Buddha are not very apt).
info.title: pacceka
info.first:
an 'Independently Enlightened One'; or Separately or Individually (=pacceka) 
Enlightened One (renderings by 'Silent' or 'Private Buddha' are not very apt).

info.titleEn2: one for whom the words are the utmost attainment.
info.title: pada
info.first: 'one for whom the words are the utmost attainment'.

info.title: padhāna
info.first:
'effort.' The 4 right efforts (samma-padhāna),
forming the 6th stage of the 8-fold Path (i.e. sammā-vāyāma, s. 
magga)
are: (1) the effort to avoid (samvara-padhāna), (2) to overcome 
(pahāna-padhāna),
(3) to develop (bhāvanā-padhāna), (4) to maintain 
(anurakkhana-padhāna),
i.e. (1) the effort to avoid unwholesome (akusala) states, such as 
evil thoughts, etc. (2) to overcome unwholesome states, (3) to develop wholesome
(kusala) states, such as the 7 elements of enlightenment (bojjhanga, 
q.v.), (4) to maintain the wholesome states.

info.title: padhāniyanga
info.first: 'elements of effort', are the following 5 qualities:

info.title: pahāna
info.first:
'overcoming', abandoning. There are 5 kinds of overcoming: (1) 
overcoming by repression (vikkhambhana-pahāna), i.e. the temporary 
suspension of the 5 hindrances (nīvarana, q.v.) during the absorptions, 
(2) overcoming by the opposite (tadanga-pahāna), (3) overcoming by 
destruction (samuccheda-pahāna), (4) overcoming by tranquillization 
(patipassaddhi-pahāna), (5) overcoming by escape (nissarana-pahāna).

info.title: palibodha
info.first:
'obstacles', is the term for the following things if they obstruct the 
monk in the strict practice of a subject of meditation: a crowded monastery, 
travelling, relatives, association with lay folk, gifts, pupils, repairs in the 
monastery, sickness, study, magical power.

info.title: pañca
info.first:
'five-group existence', is a name for existence in the sensuous sphere 
(kāmāvacara), or in the fine-material sphere (rūpāvacara, s. 
avacara), since all the 5 groups of existence (khandha, q.v.) are 
found there.

info.title: paññā
info.first:
'understanding, knowledge, wisdom, insight', comprises a very wide 
field. The specific Buddhist knowledge or wisdom, however, as part of the Noble 
Eightfold Path (magga, q.v.) to deliverance, is insight (vipassanā, 
q.v.), i.e. that intuitive knowledge which brings about the 4 stages of holiness 
and the realization of Nibbāna (s. ariyapuggala),
and which consists in the penetration of the impermanency (anicca, q.v.), 
misery (dukkha, s. sacca) and impersonality (anattā) of all 
forms of existence. Further details, s. under tilakkhana.

info.title: paññā
info.first:
'deliverance through wisdom' (or understanding'), signifies, according 
to Com. to A.V, 142, the wisdom associated with the fruition of holiness 
(arahatta-phala).

info.title: papañca
info.first:
(Sanskrit prapañca): In doctrinal usage, it signifies the 
expansion, differentiation, 'diffuseness' or 'manifoldness' of the world; and it 
may also refer to the 'phenomenal world' in general, and to the mental attitude 
of 'worldliness'.

info.title: parāmāsa
info.first: 'adherence', attachment, 'misapprehension',

info.title: paramattha
info.first:
(-sacca, -vacana, -desanā): 'truth (or term, exposition) that is 
true in the highest (or ultimate) sense', as contrasted with the 'conventional 
truth' (vohāra-sacca), which is also called 'commonly accepted truth' 
(sammuti-sacca; in Skr: samvrti-satya).

info.title: paramí
info.first: 'perfection'

info.title: parihāna
info.first: 'liable to decline'.

info.title: parinibbāna
info.first: 'full Nibbāna', is a synonym for Nibbāna;

info.title: pariññā
info.first:
'full understanding', full comprehension. There are 3 kinds of mundane 
f.u. (lokiya-p.), namely: full understanding of the known (ñāta-p.), 
f.u. as investigating (tīrana-p.), and f.u. as overcoming (pahāna-p.) 
In Vis.M. XX, 3 it is said:

info.title: pariyatti
info.first: 'learning the doctrine', the 'wording of the doctrine'.

info.title: paticcasamuppāda, dependent origination
info.first:
'dependent origination', is the doctrine of the conditionality of all 
physical and psychical phenomena, a doctrine which, together with that of 
impersonality (anattā), forms the 
indispensable condition for the real understanding and realization of the 
teaching of the Buddha. It shows the conditionality and dependent nature of that 
uninterrupted flux of manifold physical and psychical phenomena of existence 
conventionally called the ego, or man, or animal, etc.

info.title: patigha
info.first:
1. In an ethical sense, it means: 'repugnance', grudge, resentment, anger, 
and is a synonym of vyāpāda, 'ill-will' (s. nīvarana) and dosa, 
'hate' (s. mūla). It is one of the proclivities (anusaya, q.v.).

info.title: patipadā
info.first:
1. 'Road', 'path'; for instance in dukkhanirodha-gāminī-patipadā,
'the road leading to the extinction of suffering' (= 4th Noble Truth); 
majjhima-patipadā,
'the Middle Way'.

info.title: patisambhidā
info.first: 'analytical knowledge' or 'discrimination', is of 4 kinds:

info.title: patisandhi
info.first:
lit. 'reunion, relinking', i.e. rebirth, is one of the 14 functions of 
consciousness (viññāna-kicca). It 
is a karma-resultant type of consciousness and arises at the moment of 
conception i.e. with the forming of new life in the mother's womb. Immediately 
afterwards it sinks into the subconscious stream of existence (bhavangasota), 
and conditioned thereby ever and ever again corresponding states of sub 
consciousness arise. Thus it is really rebirth-consciousness that determines the 
latent character of a person.

info.title: patisankhāna
info.first:
'power of reflection', and 'power of mental development'. About these 2 
powers it is said in A. II, 10:

info.title: pativedha
info.first: 'penetration',

info.title: patti
info.first: lit. 'giving of the acquired', i.e. 'transference of merit.'

info.title: penetration s
info.first: s. pativedha, pariyatti. -

info.title: phala
info.first: lit. 'fruit'. -

info.title: phassa
info.first: (fr. phusati, to touch): 'sense-impression', contact.

info.title: píti
info.first:
rapture, enthusiasm (rendered also by joy, happiness); interest it is 
one of the mental factors or concomitants (cetasika)
and belongs to the group of mental formations (sankhāra-kkhandha).

info.title: powers
info.first: the 5 spiritual: s. bala. -

info.title: progress
info.first:
s. patipadā, abhabbagamana - p. in morality, etc., s. 
hānabhāgiya, etc. -

info.titleEn2:
Gradual development of the Eightfold Path in the: In many suttas occurs 
an identical passage that outlines the gradual course of development in the 
progress of the disciple. There it is shown how this development takes place 
gradually
info.title: progress of the disciple
info.first:
Gradual development of the Eightfold Path in the: In many suttas occurs 
an identical passage that outlines the gradual course of development in the 
progress of the disciple. There it is shown how this development takes place 
gradually, and in conformity with laws, from the very first hearing of the 
doctrine, and from germinating faith and dim comprehension, up to the final 
realization of deliverance.

info.title: puggala
info.first:
'individual', 'person', as well as the synonyms: personality, 
individuality, being (satta), self (attā), etc., in short all 
terms designating a personal entity, hence also: I, you, he, man, god, etc., all 
these, according to Buddhism, are mere names for certain combinations of 
material and mental processes, and apart from them they have no real existence. 
They are to be considered as mere 'conventional modes of expression' 
(vohāra-vacana),
and on that level they may be used, and are so used in the sutta texts, if taken 
"without misapprehending them" (s. quote from D. 9 under paramattha).
With such tacit reservations, the term puggala occurs quite frequently in 
the suttas.

info.title: punabbhava
info.first:
lit.: re-becoming; 'renewed existence', is a sutta term for 'rebirth', 
which, in later literature mostly is called patisandhi
(q.v.). The attainment of Sainthood (arahatta), implying the end of 
future rebirths, is often expressed in the words: "This is the last birth. Now 
there is no more a renewed existence!" (natthi 'dāni punabbhavo)
(M. 26; D. 15; Therag. 87, 339; Sn. 502). - The term is often linked with 
abhinibbatti
('arising').

info.title: puñña
info.first:
merit, meritorious, is a popular term for karmically wholesome 
(kusala) action.

info.title: puññā
info.first: 'streams of merit'.

info.title: puñña
info.first: 'bases of meritorious action'.

info.titleEn2: lit.: one of the many folk
info.title: puthujjana
info.first:
lit.: 'one of the many folk', 'worldling', ordinary man, is any layman 
or monk who is still possessed of all the 10 fetters
(samyojana, q.v.) binding to the round of rebirths, and therefore has not 
yet reached any of the 4 stages of holiness (s. ariya-puggala).

info.title: pújā
info.first: (1) honour, respect, homage,

info.title: rāga
info.first:
'lust', 'greed', is a synonym of lobha (s.
mūla), tanhā 
and abhijjhā (s. 
kammapatha).

info.title: rúpa
info.first:
'corporeal group', material unit, designates a combination of several 
physical phenomena constituting a temporary unity. Thus, for instance, the 
so-called 'dead matter' forms the most primitive group, consisting only of 8 
physical phenomena, called the 'pure eightfold unit' or 'octad' 
(suddhatthakakalāpa), to wit: the 4 elements (the solid, fluid, heat, 
motion); colour, smell, taste, nutriment (pathavī, āpo, tejo, vāyo; vanna, 
gandha, rasa, ojā).

info.title: sāmañña
info.first:
the 'fruits of monkhood', is the name of a famous sutta (D.2) and also, 
according to D.33, a name for the 4 supermundane fruitions:

info.titleEn2: (lit. message): the Dispensation of the Buddha
info.title: sāsana
info.first:
(lit. 'message'): the Dispensation of the Buddha, the Buddhist religion; 
teaching, doctrine.

info.titleEn2: contemplation on disinterestedness regarding the whole world
info.title: sabba
info.first: 'contemplation on disinterestedness regarding the whole world',

info.title: sacca
info.first: 'Truth'.

info.title: sacca
info.first: 'knowledge of the truth' (s. prec.), may be of 2 kinds:

info.title: sacchikaraníyā dhammā
info.first: 'things to be realized'.

info.title: saddhā
info.first: faith, confidence.

info.title: sakkāya
info.first: 'existing group', 'this word is usually translated by 'personality',

info.title: sakkāya
info.first: 'personality-belief', is the first of the 10 fetters (samyojana).

info.titleEn2: one who attains two ends simultaneously
info.title: sama
info.first: one 'who attains two ends simultaneously',

info.titleEn2:
concentration; lit. the (mental) state of being firmly fixed 
(sam+ā+√ hā)
info.title: samādhi
info.first:
'concentration'; lit. 'the (mental) state of being firmly fixed' 
(sam+ā+√ hā),

info.title: samāpatti
info.first: 'attainments',

info.title: samatha
info.first: 'tranquillity', serenity, is a synonym of

info.title: samatha
info.first:
'tranquillity and insight', are identical with concentration 
(samādhi, q.v.; s. prec.) and wisdom (paññā,
q.v.), and form the two branches of mental development (bhāvanā, q.v.).

info.title: sammā
info.first:
'Perfect Enlightenment', Universal Buddha-hood, is the state attained by 
a Universal Buddha (sammā-sambuddha), i.e. one by whom the liberating law 
(dhamma) which had become lost to the world, has again been discovered, 
realized and clearly proclaimed to the world.

info.title: sammasana
info.first:
'comprehension', exploring, 'determining' (vavatthāna,
q.v.)

info.title: sampadā
info.first: 'attainment, blessing'. The 5 blessings are said to be (A.V.91):

info.title: sampajañña
info.first:
'clarity of consciousness', clear comprehension. This term is frequently 
met with in combination with mindfulness
(sati). In D. 22, M. 10 it is said: "Clearly conscious is he in going and 
coming, clearly conscious in looking forward and backward, clearly conscious in 
bending and stretching his body; clearly conscious in eating, drinking, chewing 
and tasting, clearly conscious in discharging excrement and urine; clearly 
conscious in walking, standing, sitting, falling asleep and awakening; clearly 
conscious in speaking and keeping silent." - For a definition of the term 
sati-sampajañña, s. Pug. 86.

info.title: sampaticchana
info.first:
'receptive consciousness', is the mindelement (mano-dhātu) that 
follows immediately upon the arising of sense-consciousness (visual 
consciousness, etc.), performing on that occasion the function of recciving the 
sense-object.

info.title: samsāra
info.first:
'round of rebirth', lit. perpetual wandering', is a name by which is 
designated the sea of life ever restlessly heaving up and down, the symbol of 
this continuous process of ever again and again being born, growing old, 
suffering and dying.

info.title: samseva
info.first: 'companionship'.

info.title: samuccheda
info.first:
'overcoming by destruction', is the absolute extinction of certain 
fetters of existence (samyojana, q.v.), which takes place by entering 
into one of the 4 supermundane paths of holiness (s. ariya-puggala). -

info.title: samutthāna
info.first: 'origination'.

info.title: samvega
info.first: 'the sources of emotion',

info.title: samvejaníya
info.first: 'places rousing emotion', are 4:

info.title: samyojana
info.first: 'fetters'.

info.title: sangha
info.first: (lit.: congregation), is the name for the Community of Buddhist monks.

info.title: sankhāra
info.first:
This term has, according to its context, different shades of meaning, 
which should be carefully distinguished.

info.titleEn2: the equanimity-knowledge with regard to the formations of existence
info.title: sankhārupekkhā
info.first: the 'equanimity-knowledge with regard to the formations of existence',

info.title: saññā
info.first:
1. 'perception', is one of the 5 groups of existence (khandha, 
q.v.), and one of the 7 mental factors (cetasika) that are inseparably 
bound up with all consciousness (s. cetanā). It is sixfold as perception 
of the 5 physical sense-objects and of mental objects. It is the awareness of an 
object's distinctive marks ("one perceives blue, yellow, etc.," S. XXII, 79). 
If, in repeated perception of an object, these marks are recognized, saññā 
functions as 'memory' (s. Abh. St., p. 68f.).

info.title: santāna
info.first: 'continuity', may refer to

info.title: sasankhārika
info.first: (in Dhs.: sasankhārena )

info.title: sassata
info.first: 'eternity-belief',

info.title: sati
info.first: 'mindfulness', is

info.title: satipatthāna
info.first:
the 4 'foundations of mindfulness', lit. 'awareness of mindfulness' 
(sati-upatthāna), are:

info.title: satta
info.first: 'living being'.

info.title: sattāvāsa
info.first: 'abodes of beings'.

info.title: sekha
info.first:
a 'noble learner', a disciple in higher training, i.e. one who pursues 
the 3 kinds of training (sikkhā), is one of 
those 7 kinds of noble disciples who have reached one of the 4 supermundane 
paths or the 3 lower fruitions (s. 
ariya-puggala), while the one possessed of the 4th fruition, or 
Arahatta-phala, is called 'one beyond training' (asekha, lit. 'no more 
learner').

info.title: senāsana
info.first:
'dwelling place', is one of the 4 requisites of the monk's life (s. 
sīla 4).

info.title: síla
info.first:
'morality', 'virtue', is a mode of mind and volition (cetana) 
manifested in speech or bodily action (s. 
karma). It is the foundation of the whole 
Buddhist practice, and therewith the first of the 3 kinds of training (sikkhā) 
that form the 3-fold division of the 8-fold Path (s. 
magga), i.e. morality, concentration and wisdom.

info.titleEn2: attachment (or clinging) to mere rules and ritual
info.title: sílabbata
info.first:
'attachment (or clinging) to mere rules and ritual', is the 3rd of the 10 
fetters (samyojana), and one of the 4 kinds 
of clinging (upādāna).

info.title: sívathikā
info.first: 'cemetery contemplations', as described in D.22 and M.10,

info.title: sikkhā
info.first: the 'training', which the Buddha's disciple has to undergo, is 3-fold:

info.title: sikkhāpada
info.first: 'steps of training', moral rules.

info.title: sobhana
info.first:
'lofty', beautiful, pure, are called, in Abh. S., all states of 
consciousness excepting the unwholesome and those without roots (ahetuka).

info.title: somanassa
info.first:
lit 'glad-minded-ness' (su+manas+ya),
gladness, joy; identical with 'mentally agreeable feeling' (cetasikā sukhā 
vedanā), belongs to the feeling-group (vedanā-kkhandha, s. khandha
II), and is enumerated amongst the 22 faculties (indriya, q.v.).

info.title: sotāpanna
info.first:
the 'Stream-winner', is the lowest of the 8 noble disciples (s. 
ariya-puggala).

info.titleEn2: the characteristic qualities of a Stream-winner are 4:
info.title: sotāpannassa angāni
info.first: the 'characteristic qualities of a Stream-winner' are 4:

info.title: sotāpattiyanga
info.first: the 4 (preliminary) 'conditions to Stream-entry' are:

info.title: subha
sucarita
info.first: 'good conduct', is 3-fold, in

info.title: suddhāvāsa
info.first:
the 'Pure Abodes', are a group of 5 heavens belonging to the 
fine-material world (rūpa-loka, s. loka), where only the 
Non-returners (s. anāgāmī, q.v.) are reborn, and in which they attain 
Arahatship and Nibbāna (ariya-puggala).

info.title: sukha
info.first: pleasant, happy; happiness, pleasure, joy, bliss.

info.title: sukkha
info.first:
'one supported by bare insight', is the commentarial term for one who, 
without having attained any of the meditative absorptions (jhāna, q.v.), 
has realized only by the support of insight (vipassanā, q.v.) one or several of the supermundane paths (s. ariyapuggala).

info.title: suñña
info.first: void (ness), empty (emptiness).

info.title: tadārammana
info.first:
'registering consciousness' (s. Tab. I, 40-49, 56), is the last stage in 
the complete process of cognition (citta-vīthi) immediately before sinking into 
the subconscious.

info.title: tanhā
info.first:
(lit. 'thirst'): 'craving', is the chief root of suffering, and of the 
ever-continuing cycle of rebirths. "What, o monks, is the origin of suffering? 
It is that craving which gives rise to ever-fresh rebirth and, bound up with 
pleasure and lust, now here, now there, finds ever fresh delight. It is the

info.title: tathāgata
info.first:
the 'Perfect One', lit. the one who has 'thus gone', or 'thus come', is 
an epithet of the Buddha used by him when speaking of himself.

info.title: tathatā
info.first:
'Suchness', designates the firmly fixed nature (bhāva)
of all things whatever.

info.title: tatra
info.first:
'equanimity, equipoise, mental balance' (lit., 'remaining here and there 
in the middle'), is the name for a high ethical quality belonging to the 
sankhāra-kkhandha (s. khandha)
and is mostly known by the name upekkhā.

info.titleEn2: one endowed with the threefold (higher) knowledge.
info.title: te
info.first: 'one endowed with the threefold (higher) knowledge'.

info.title: theravāda
info.first:
'Doctrine of the Elders', is a name of the oldest form of the Buddha's 
teachings, handed down to us in the Pāli language.

info.title: thína
info.first: 'sloth and torpor',

info.title: ti
info.first:
the '3 characteristics of existence', or signata, are impermanency (anicca), 
suffering or misery (dukkha; s. 
sacca, dukkhatā), 
not-self (anattā).

info.title: ti
info.first:
'Three Jewels' or Three Gems, which by all Buddhists are revered as the 
most venerable things, are

info.title: ti
info.first:
'Threefold Refuge', in which every faithful adherent of the Buddha puts 
his whole trust, consists in the Buddha, the Dhamma and the Sangha (s. prec.).

info.title: ti
info.first:
'The Three Baskets', is the name for the 3 main divisions of the Pāli 
Canon:

info.title: tiracchāna
info.first:
'low talk', lit. 'beastly talk', is the name in the sutta-texts for the 
following:

info.titleEn2:
the 3 articles of (heretical) belief. which in A.III.61 are declared 
as leading to inactivity
info.title: titthāyatana
info.first:
the 3 'articles of (heretical) belief'. which in A.III.61 are declared 
as leading to inactivity, are:

info.title: ubhato
info.first:
the 'both-ways-liberated one', is the name of one class of noble 
disciples (ariya-puggala, q.v.). He is liberated in 2 ways, namely, by 
way of all 8 absorptions (jhāna, q.v.) as well as by the supermundane 
path (sotāpatti, etc.) based on insight (vipassanā,
q.v.). In M. 70 it is said:

info.title: uddhacca
info.first:
'restlessness', belongs to the 10 fetters (samyojana), 
and to the 5 hindrances (nīvarana).

info.titleEn2:
one who already during a given explanation comes to penetrate the 
truth (Pug.).
info.title: ugghatitaññu
info.first:
'one who already during a given explanation comes to penetrate the 
truth' (Pug.).

info.title: upādāna
info.first:
'clinging', according to Vis.M. XVII, is an intensified degree of craving 
(tanhā).

info.title: upādi
info.first:
lit. 'something which one grasps, to which one clings, i.e. the 5 groups 
of existence (khandha, q.v.).

info.title: upādinna
upāsaka
info.first:
lit. 'sitting close by', i.e. a 'lay adherent', is any lay follower who 
is filled with faith and has taken refuge in the Buddha, his doctrine and his 
community of noble disciples (A.VIII.25).

info.title: upadhi
info.first: 'substratum of existence'.

info.title: upakkilesa
info.first:
'impurities', corruptions, imperfections (a frequent rendering by 
'defilements' is better reserved for 
kilesa).

info.titleEn2: recollection of the peace of Nibbāna
info.title: upasamānussati
info.first:
'recollection of the peace of Nibbāna', is the last of the 10 recollections 
(anussati, q.v.).

info.title: upekkhā
info.first:
'equanimity', also called tatra-majjhattatā, is an ethical quality belonging to the sankhāra-group (s.
khandha) and should therefore not be confounded with indifferent feeling 
(adukkha-m-asukhā vedanā) which sometimes also is called upekkhā (s. 
vedanā).

info.title: uposatha
info.first: lit. 'fasting', i.e. 'fasting day',

info.title: vací
info.first: 'verbal karma-formation', or 'verbal function'.

info.titleEn2: mastery. Vis.M. IV speaks of 5 kinds of m.
info.title: vasí
info.first:
'mastery'. Vis.M. IV speaks of 5 kinds of m., which anyone who wishes to 
develop the absorptions (jhāna, q.v.) should acquire first of all, with 
regard to the 1st absorption, namely:

info.titleEn2: (1) With reference to the dependent origination (paticcasamuppāda)
info.title: vatta
info.first:
(1) With reference to the dependent origination (paticcasamuppāda), 
Vis.M. XVII speaks of 3 rounds:

info.title: vatthu
info.first:
'physical base', i.e. the 6 physical organs on which the mental process 
is based, are the 5 physical sense-organs and, according to the Com., the heart 
(hadaya-vatthu, q.v.) as the 6th.

info.title: vavatthāna
info.first:
'determining', defining. In its application to insight meditation, this 
term occurred first in Pts.M. (I, p. 53); but in a verbal form, as a past 
participle, already in M.111: tyassa dhammā anupada-vavatthitā honti, 
"these things (the mental factors) were determined by him (i.e. Sāriputta) 
successively" (s. Abh. St., p. 54).

info.title: vedanā
info.first:
'feeling', sensation, is the 2nd of the 5 groups of existence (s. 
khandha II).

info.titleEn2: self-confidence of a Buddha is fourfold.
info.title: vesārajja
info.first: 'self-confidence' of a Buddha is fourfold.

info.titleEn2:
analytical or discriminating doctrine is an early name for the 
original Buddha doctrine
info.title: vibhajja
info.first:
'analytical or discriminating doctrine' is an early name for the 
original Buddha doctrine, called Theravāda. -

info.title: vicikicchā
info.first:
'sceptical doubt', is one of the 5 mental hindrances (nīvarana) 
and one of the 3 fetters (samyojana), 
which disappear for ever at Stream-entry, the first stage of holiness (s.
ariya-puggala).

info.title: vihāra
info.first: 'abode'

info.title: vijjā
info.first: knowledge and conduct'.

info.title: vimokkha
info.first: 'liberation' (deliverance). I. the 3; II. the 8.

info.title: vimutti
info.first: 'deliverance', is of 2 kinds:

info.title: vinipāta
info.first: 'world of suffering',

info.title: viññāna
viññāna
info.first:
'functions of consciousness', as exercised within a process of 
consciousness or cognitive series (cittavīthi).
In the Abhidhamma Com. and Vis.M. XIV the following functions are mentioned:

info.titleEn2:
abodes or supports of consciousness. The texts describe 7 such abodes 
(e.g. A.VII.41):
info.title: viññāna
info.first:
'abodes or supports of consciousness'. The texts describe 7 such abodes 
(e.g. A.VII.41):

info.title: viññatti
info.first:
(lit. 'making known') 'intimation', is an Abhidhamma term for bodily 
expression (kāya-viññatti) and verbal expression (vacī-viññatti), 
both belonging to the corporeality-group. They are produced by the co-nascent 
volition, and are therefore, as such, purely physical and not to be confounded 
with karma (q.v.), which as such is something mental. Cf. Kath. 80, 100, 101, 
103, 194 (s. Guide V). - (App.).

info.title: vipāka
info.first:
'karma-result', is any karmically (morally) neutral mental phenomenon 
(e.g. bodily agreeable or painful feeling, sense-consciousness, etc. ), which is 
the result of wholesome or unwholesome volitional action (karma, q.v.) through 
body, speech or mind, done either in this or some previous life.

info.title: vipallāsa
info.first: 'perversions' or 'distortions'. -

info.title: vipassanā
info.first:
'insight', is the intuitive light flashing forth and exposing the truth 
of the impermanency, the suffering and the impersonal and unsubstantial nature 
of all corporeal and mental phenomena of existence. It is insight-wisdom 
(vipassanā-paññā) that is the decisive liberating factor in Buddhism, though 
it has to be developed along with the 2 other trainings in morality and 
concentration. The culmination of insight practice (s. 
visuddhi VI) leads directly to the stages of holiness (s. visuddhi
VII).

info.title: vipatti
info.first:
'aberration' or 'deviation', may be: deviation from morality 
(sīla-vipatti), or deviation from understanding (ditthivipatti).

info.title: virāga
info.first:
'fading away', detachment; absence of lust, dispassionateness. Appears 
frequently together with nirodha, 'cessation'

info.title: virati
info.first: the 3 'abstentions' or abstinences, are:

info.title: viriya
info.first:
'energy', lit. 'virility', 'manliness' or 'heroism' (from vīra, 
man, hero; Lat. vir; cf. virtus),

info.title: visuddhi
info.first: 'purification', purity.

info.title: vitakka
info.first:
'thought', 'thought-conception', is one of the 'secondary' (not 
constant) mental concomitants (s. Tab. II), and may 
be either karmically wholesome, unwholesome or neutral. -

info.title: vitakka
info.first:
'thought-conception and discursive thinking', (or 'applied and sustained 
thought') are verbal functions (vacī-sankhāra:
s. sankhāra) of the mind, the so-called 'inner speech ('parole 
interieure'). They are constituents of the 1st absorption (s. 
jhāna), but absent in the higher 
absorptions.

info.title: viveka
info.first: 'detachment', seclusion, is according to Niddesa, of 3 kinds:

info.title: viveka
info.first: 'happiness of detachment', or aloofness (s. prec).

info.title: vodāna
info.first:
'cleansing', may refer either to (1) morality (sīla),
or (2) concentration (samādhi), or (3) wisdom (paññā).

info.title: votthapana
info.first:
'determining consciousness', is that mindelement (functioning 
independently of karma; s. Tab. I, 70) which in the process of sense-perception 
performs the function of determining the sense-object.

info.titleEn2:
insight leading to (path) ascent. It is also called cleansing 
(vodāna
info.title: vutthāna
info.first:
'insight leading to (path) ascent'. It is also called 'cleansing' 
(vodāna, q.v.), and according to Pts.M. II, 64, it is a name for 3 kinds of 
insight-knowledge, namely: knowledge consisting in the desire for deliverance 
(muccitu-kamyatā-ñāna; s. visuddhi
VI 6); reflecting-contemplation-knowledge (patisankhānupassanā-ñāna; ib. 
VI, 7); and knowledge consisting in equanimity regarding all formations 
(sankhārupekkhā-ñāna;
s. visuddhi VI, 8).

info.title: yamaka
info.first: 'twin miracle'.
